body:
@nauerz-ibm previously mentioned that the wsk CLI should have parity with the Bluemix CLI's architecture/CPU support.  The Bluemix CLI download page http://clis.ng.bluemix.net/ui/home.html lists the following platform/architectures:
- Mac OS X 
- Linux 64-bit (need to confirm CPU)
- Windows 64-bit

Bluemix provides an installer for the Mac and Windows and a tgz for Linux.  Currently the OpenWhisk CLI is pretty simple, so perhaps just downloading the binary is sufficient.
I am fairly sure this is because you are using port `2376` instead of `4243`. You can look at the invoker logs and confirm if it's trying to start containers on docker host with port `4243`.
+1 had to do the same and should be documented.
:+1: on only pulling in `redo` to push ant further away in our daily lives.

@ChrBi working on missing tests

@csantanapr you know if that is documented? can you make a proposal where to document pls?

the problem is the mount point of invoker, pls see https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/199.

The `clean` mode works in the same order like the `deploy` mode. At this moment, the user action containers are deleted but the invoker is still there.

So, i suggest to close this issue

> unless i link python to /usr/local/bin on my mac host, I get this error (post setup and prereq)

@rabbah how did you install python on your mac? I did using brew which installs it to `/usr/local/bin/python` which is why we added the `ansible_python_interpreter=/usr/local/bin/python` setting in the mac environment for ansible. If you installed using a different way that would cause the issue you mentioned.
Python was already on my Mac. I didn't reinstall it. I expect this will be common. Why not use whereis/which instead of hard coding a path.

i think, the README.md for ansible should only cover the part: how to deploy openwhisk with ansible. The overall README would take the part of ansible README for deploying and add post steps like setting up api key, etc..

What do you think @rabbah @jeremiaswerner @domdom82
we still use port `4243`  for docker, not port `2376`
did you deploy the ephemeral couch at first?
correct, due to #199. this is a known problem, so i suggest to close this issue
it said `10.0.2.15 invalid host`. which env did you use? can you paste it here?
which env did you use here? vagrant? which machine has `10.0.2.15` ?
A link to a next step is logical - in particular how to verify the deployment is operational. This is in scope for ansible readme.
@rabbah : the python path is in the docker-machine where python is installed via tce. _not_ your python in your mac.

@lehoanganh there is a bug in the group_vars all which breaks @rabbah :

```
[all:vars]
ansible_connection=ssh
ansible_user=docker
ansible_ssh_private_key_file=~/.docker/machine/machines/{{ docker_machine_name | default("whisk")}}/id_rsa
ansible_python_interpreter=/usr/local/bin/python
```

the "all" param also includes the "ansible" host which is the local host. so it will also affect where python is found locally. should be more like 

```
[all:!ansible:vars]
```

if that works... which it doesn't
rebase and merged bce6eb86a3cde3ab12354ea158a0ce1708ff993a

HI @mdeuser Also checkout the Cloud Foundry CLI release page, the offer both Installers and Binaries

I think we can start by offering binaries. but if you take a look closely the binaries are tgz for Linux and Mac, and zip for Windows.
If there is savings in download payload by compressing I would suggest we also do the same and offer a compressed payload to help speed the downloads.

@rabbah @psuter @jeremiaswerner 
guys, can we agree to first merge this in the old state "as is" to finalize the shift from blue to open and then handle the quality improvements of the sdk in a separate issue? otherwise this is kinda blocked now..
@rabbah is this ready for review? it has WIP in the title. So not sure if you are in the middle of adding something else.

i see at least some broken things here that we should fix first rather than merging in something that's broken. in particular, `if (status === Status.ready) {`. The sdk is already not in openwhisk and would rather not add it in a broken state. i'll concede deferring the dockerfile/package.json clean up (although really not that much work to just remove them now). but i think the proxy server is broken, and the test should be tightened.
@markusthoemmes Is this PR related any open issue?

I am debating a test. Thoughts? It is otherwise reviewable.
Shall we document it also?
Yeah, to #626 it's linked via commit message (also added a link to the description now)

I'd like to continue this discussion (focused on the original topic of this issue) here:

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/wiki/Design-Discussion-on-javascript-context

@rabbah @domdom82 @lehoanganh current deployments are broken due to missing SDK's. we need to deliver this asap. pls let us focus on the core functionality first. we should do any bug fixes, tests, extra feature, enhancement, ... in an additional PR.

@jeremiaswerner OPTIONS is not documented since it's not implemented.

Need to documented in two places
1. In swagger json file for the API
2. It would be good to put a note about supporting CORS in reference.md in REST API section
same issue to me. I can run testing after the first time deployment. But connection fail after couples of minute.

I think we should have tests and documented if we are going to merge the feature.

We can run a docker container to run a socks proxy for the test, the same setup/test can be use for the go-cli also.

I found this one: https://github.com/shadowsocks/shadowsocks-libev
It's GPL but since we are going to include as part of dpeloyment just use it blackbox only for the CI test it should be OK right?
Update: the bluemix v2 UI now exposes timeout and memory quotas to the user. for now, we're (unpleasantly) hard-coding things in the UI: min, max, and default limits.

closing with 3796dbeeef9dd882b3b7d94e21ca4ff3de09af94

close with 75f6615e37b54a7a9d01272c2cac60570fb787b2

I was not able to get docker-machine to recognize port 4243, how to you tell/configure docker-machine use 4243 instead of 2376  when you do `docker-machine ls` I has getting status unknown.

I don't understand why we are using this special port, and we have it in many places hardcoded, it should be in one place to be easy to change and test.

can we move back to default 2376?
PPG 626 for the additional change I made.

@markusthoemmes duh! didn't see the "Fixes #626" which I open, double duh !

adding max, it will required to also add min, then it will make the table to cluttered

Hi @nicolelovecoding 
It will be helpful if you could provide steps to reproduce with some generic sample code.

I'm going to assume that you have a javascript action using default runtime nodejs 0.12
That you are using the request library provided by npm package request
trying to do some type of http request to a web service or web site.
And you are getting this error.

If you know that that the endpoint you are trying to reach is a valid one, and that it happens to timeout sometimes and you want to retry, you will need to write the logic, or use an npm package like [node-request-retry](https://www.npmjs.com/package/node-request-retry)

The problem is that the nodejs runtime only has a fix number of npm package already pre-installed and node-request-retry is not.

You can use an npm package that is not available by default by bundling 3rd party dependencies into your javascript action, take a look at the following article on how they use webpack to achieve this.
https://developer.ibm.com/openwhisk/2016/03/17/bundling-openwhisk-actions-with-webpack/

For reference on which packages are available for default you can look at the [source code](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/nodejsAction/Dockerfile) or the [reference doc](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/reference.md#runtime-environment)

hope this helps, let us know how else we can help.
I think I try both CouchDB and Cloudant
cool thing!
@dubeejw any updates on this?
@markusthoemmes yes we can close as dup as long we copy the requirements and add them to #335
@csantanapr want to give this a pass documentationwise?

@markusthoemmes Changes to reference.md LGTM
@ChriBi always feel free to reach out directly to me
did you move the tests from blue that do the same?

I don't see any objections on why we shouldn't follow the convention. Pull request very welcome!

The link to certain projects (i.e. loadbalancer) is "works as designed". Which problems do you experience with the files otherwise?

@csantanapr   I think kafka issue was solved after mem param modification. But the issue 
error: name 'C:' contains illegal characters (code 29)
still happens, any workaround?

case to reproduce:
$ vagrant ssh -- wsk action invoke /whisk.system/samples/echo -p message hello --blocking --result
error: name 'C:' contains illegal characters (code 70)

I setup up my open whisk in  C:\workspace,in git bash command it is /c/workspace
case which do not have the problem:
$ vagrant ssh
$ wsk action invoke /whisk.system/samples/echo -p message hello --blocking --result

{
    "message": "hello"
}
=> correct
@csantanapr I probably do. I used the "copy path" function in git because I wanted to avoid ".."

loadBalancer is not linked at controller project (as it should).
controller project is linked to dispatcher src (instead of controller src)

I'm using Scala IDE 4.4.1
Build id: 4.4.1-vfinal-2016-05-04T11:16:00Z-Typesafe
The link to dispatcher src is not necessary and about to get removed in #578. I agree the linking should be at project level otherwise instead of src if that's the suggestion.

Hi! We have a slack right over here: https://dwopen.slack.com
You can get yourself an invite over there: https://developer.ibm.com/open/slackin/
Discussion on OpenWhisk takes place in #openwhisk, come join us!
The invite page only opens a blank page for me.

Yes it looks like it requests some stuff over HTTP. You can enable the loading of unsafe scripts at the top right of your adress bar.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2430239/16046559/2fa790ea-324d-11e6-936e-f23c4d73e028.png) 
You could also use http://slackindwo.mybluemix.net/ instead.

Ah thanks @lfzCarlosC I will send a pull request to increase the mem to 4GB. I was hoping not require a high memory for the simple scenario.
I think I'm going to merge both simple and custom, into a single one and always share the folder.

About error: name 'C:' contains illegal characters (code 70)
I don't have workaround to get it `vagrant ssh --` on your windows. but other have success like @dubeejw 
But have some questions for this specific error:
1. Are you using simple or custom? or you getting the error on both?
2. Are you saying that if you first vagrant ssh, and then run `wsk` from inside the VM it's correct, but running using the vagrant shortcut `vagrant ssh --` is not correct?
3. How did you setup ssh on windows that vagrant is using? native ssh, cygwin ssh, etc..
@dubeejw I know you use windows and ssh, and you install ssh, what ssh works for you?
4. How you fix the problems with `\r` in linux scripts? I want to document how to setup git for windows users when using the share folder with linux
5. Can you try to upgrade virtualbox to the latest version.

It looks like you have two workarounds:
1. use wsk from inside the vm after `vagrant ssh` like you posted
2. configure the outside wsk cli on windows with the apihost and key of the vagrant vm, maybe create a script to make it easy to swift from something like bluemix openwhisk and your VM running openwhisk.
http://slackindwo.mybluemix.net/  may be a better signup page.

Hi Stephen, can we do this as part of the "openwhisk-catalog" move? See issue #2  
[https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/issues/2](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/issues/2)

in the new openwhisk-catalog repo.  

We can create that issue there or I can amend #2 to include  echo.js.
@houshengbo Please be aware of this as part of issue #2 for the catalog move.

@domdom82 We are waiting on you  
Please provide things to try (what files to change) to see if it will fix it

@csantanapr 1. When I execute the custom ,I got issue "symbolic link wsk : protocol error"  before I could ran wsk action command.  So I do not know if the issue exists on custom.
2. Yes,  I would say the termnial would get error as presented above.
3. I setup git bash or cygwin, the issue exists on both terminal.I just download installation file and then install on GUI, then I follow the openwhisk guide.

 For the 4th questions,I could provide some error info I encountered but I was blocked by the issue "symbolic link wsk : protocol error". 
1.  there are many scripts which has "command not found: \r ", to sole the issue,execute following command on your openwhisk directory:
 find ./ -name "_.sh" -print | xargs  dos2unix
2. after you solved the 1st issue, you will then get  "Syntax error: invalid syntax " ,this is because various kind of script(gradle,python,java,....) has the format of ^M . execute following command on your openwhisk directory:    [a.txt](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/files/314274/a.txt)
find ./ -type f  -name "_" -print | xargs sed -i 's/[ \t]*$//'
Then comes the "symbolic link wsk : protocol error" issue.

Also, we now want to use openwhisk command line to make our projects from cloud side also be runnable on local host environment. Do you think this Hello vm can suit this demand?

@dubeejw   could you show your steps and all tools you use that you do on your windows paltform.
Don't want to merge this in because it will brake developers using windows (vagrant share folder). See https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/601

Proposed solution: Edit ansible.cfg in your openwhisk/ansible dir as follows:

```
[defaults]
(...)
remote_tmp = /tmp/ansible/remote_tmp
local_tmp = /tmp/ansible/local_tmp
```
Thanks @domdom82 for the info, @dubeejw give it a try and report back.

When using HTTP, every client has to make sure to always send urlencoded parts in their URL. I'ld suggest to fix this in `webhook.js` as it is essentially the client. Passing a urlencoded name to a feed not using HTTP as its backend connection might induce strange problem aswell.
Build broken, not sure why :-(

Doesn't look related to your change, restarted the build.

Edit: there you go, all green.

Yes, node-request-retry is not installed -- as @csantanapr posted above, you can work around this as follows:

   The problem is that the nodejs runtime only has a fix number of npm package already pre-installe d and node-request-retry is not.

   You can use an npm package that is not available by default by bundling 3rd party dependencies into your javascript action, take a look at the following article on how they use webpack to achieve this.
https://developer.ibm.com/openwhisk/2016/03/17/bundling-openwhisk-actions-with-webpack/

@csantanapr  I'd suggest we add this package to our base images.
I already provided an answer in my comment above https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/640#issuecomment-225763663
reopening -- repurposing this as feature request to add requestretry to standard base image.
@rabbah @csantanapr added fix for windows vagrant
final solution is to export ANSIBLE_REMOTE_TEMP=/home/vagrant/openwhisk/ansible/tmp for vagrant installations. fixed in #605
OK -- I believe I have reproduced this problem.
@psuter review and merge.

The problem is that your URL is an internal IBM address (in the stage1/YS1 bluemix).   Whisk actions can only talk to addresses in the public internet.    You'd need to deploy your endpoint in the public bluemix.
Ok, thanks!
Tweaked and merged as e11a92d626ef0c171ef39d58ea78738d51e977ed.

Note: corrected description above - `action error` to `developer error`.

Credit for the following to @psuter who originally authored it:

The intended meaning of the status was as follows:
- `"success"`: it all worked out
- `"application error"`: the action writer decided to terminate with an error (e.g. the submitted arguments are invalid). This is what you get if you call e.g. `whisk.error(..)` in JS.
- `"developer error"`: the action writer made a mistake (e.g. not handling a specific case resulted in a crash, or the action didn't return a JSON object)
- `"internal error"`: something went wrong in Whisk itself.

@csantanapr FYI for docs.

thx @rabbah .

which category would an action timeout fall into?

@rabbah what is the rationale for returning a 200 for an app error? if the args submitted were wrong, i as a dev wouldn't consider that to be a 200? (for the docs, your writeup above should include the respective http return code)

@mbehrendt timeout should fall into `"developer error"`, since they are to blame if they cannot terminate gracefully within the timeout they set themselves.

On the rationale for `200`; the problem is that there is no HTTP code that can capture all possible application errors, e.g.:
- an invalid argument could arguably trigger a `4xx` (client error)
- an issue connecting to a database or REST API could conceivably trigger a `5xx` (server-side error)

So we settled for `200` as carrying a meaning close to: "the action behaved according to the developer's explicit intent".

At a higher-level, it's useful to keep in mind that Whisk actions are conceptually _not_ HTTP endpoints, although they can be consumed as such. The mapping between activation results and HTTP codes will therefore necessarily be imperfect.

thx @psuter .

i'm wondering whether timeout deserves its own state -- given it's a very special state, and it might happen relatively often (not only due to code runtime issues, but maybe an external dependency is slow). i think having a separate state for timeout would make the system more dev-friendly, since it would be very obvious what the root cause of the issue is vs. having to investigate various possible root causes of 'dev error'. also, i think a timeout shouldn't be reflected with a 200, which would be easy to address if there was a separate state for it.

re 200 -- in my mind, it would also benefit dev / ops friendliness if we only returned a 200 if everything was fully ok. the general understanding of a 200 is that _everything_ was alright. however, with the semantics you described above, i as someone operating a whisk-based app can not be sure about that. i will always have to take the extra step of parsing the json, which is sth many monitoring are not suitable for. is there a strong reason to not do that?

@mbehrendt per #642 a timeout will be clearly reflected with a proper message. Also note that while we have these categories, every error is supplied with an error message describing what happened.

You're right though that you need to parse JSON to access that data.

@markusthoemmes with 'message' you're referring to 'statusMessage' or 'result'? where are those msgs documented? what is the rationale for embedding timeout in a msg vs. exposing it as a dedicated state and error code?
as another state to consider -- how do we react when an invocation gets throttled and therefore not executed? a 429? does that also return a json?
@mbehrendt which HTTP code would you then use for application errors?
i think invalid parameters could be separated out as a separate issue and return a 40x for that. a code issue in an action should probably be a 50x
